Remarks: India's first satellite. Power failure halted experiments after 4 days.
TV camera malfunctioned but other instruments worked as intended.
Launch vehicle was unsuccessful; satellite did not achieve orbit.
First successful launch using India's own launch vehicle (SLV-3).
Did not achieve the desired altitude  leading to a shorter orbital life of 9 days.
India's first experimental geostationary communication satellite.
Provided valuable remote sensing data.
Deactivated after solar sail failed to deploy and control fuel was exhausted.
Successfully operated for 17 months with its smart sensor camera.
Served for more than its designed life.
First developmental launch of ASLV failed. Did not achieve orbit.
First operational Indian Remote Sensing satellite.
Second developmental launch of ASLV failed.
A power system failure cut its operational life in half.
Final satellite of the first-generation INSAT series.
Identical to IRS-1A; continued the remote sensing program.
Achieved a lower than planned orbit reducing its lifespan.
First satellite of the indigenously built second-generation INSAT series.
Joined INSAT-2A in orbit.
First developmental launch of PSLV failed.
First successful launch of the ASLV.
First successful operational launch of PSLV.
Enhanced communication capabilities with Ku-band transponders.
Carried advanced remote sensing cameras.
Carried payloads for earth observation and X-ray astronomy.
Lost due to an on-board power bus anomaly shortly after launch.
Achieved a lower-than-planned orbit but was still partially usable.
Carried communication and meteorological payloads.
First Indian satellite primarily built for oceanographic applications.
Augmented the communication services of INSAT system.
Did not reach the intended orbit due to GSLV upper stage underperformance.
Used to test technologies for future reconnaissance satellites.
Provided voice  video and digital data services.
First dedicated meteorological satellite built by ISRO.
Multipurpose satellite for telecom  television  and meteorological services.
Experimental satellite to test new communication technologies.
Exclusively for communication services.
Provided data for agriculture,  disaster management, and land use.
India's first satellite built exclusively to serve the educational sector.
Microsatellite for providing satellite-based amateur radio services.
Provided high-resolution, stereo imagery for cartographic applications.
First in the INSAT-4 series, primarily for DTH television services.
Suffered a power anomaly in 2010, which reduced its capacity.
An experimental space capsule which was successfully recovered after 12 days.
Advanced remote sensing satellite with a panchromatic camera.
Placed in a lower orbit than planned, which reduced its expected mission life.
Dedicated satellite for the Indian Armed Forces.
A low-cost microsatellite for remote sensing.
India's first lunar probe. Confirmed the presence of water molecules on the Moon.
Radar imaging satellite used for surveillance and disaster management.
Provided data for oceanography and atmospheric studies.
Launch vehicle failed and was destroyed by range safety 63 seconds after liftoff.
Similar to previous Cartosat satellites for high-resolution imaging.
Duplicate entry from list; refers to the same failed launch of GSLV-F06.
A follow-on mission to Resourcesat-1 to provide data continuity.
An Indo-Russian satellite for stellar and atmospheric research.
Carried Ku-band transponders and the GAGAN navigation payload.
Replaced the services of the aged INSAT-3B satellite.
An Indo-French joint mission to study the tropical atmosphere and climate.
India's first indigenous all-weather Radar Imaging Satellite.
Carried communication transponders and the GAGAN payload.
A joint Indo-French mission for studying the ocean's surface and sea level.
First satellite in the NAVIC constellation. Its atomic clocks later failed.
Advanced meteorological satellite with improved imaging and an atmospheric sounder.
India's first dedicated military communications satellite.
India's first interplanetary mission. Made ISRO the fourth agency to reach Mars.
First successful flight of GSLV with an indigenous cryogenic upper stage.
Second satellite of the NAVIC navigation system.
Third satellite of the NAVIC navigation system.
A multi-band telecom satellite to augment communication services.
Crew module Atmospheric Re-entry Experiment on the first test flight of LVM3.
Fourth satellite of the NAVIC navigation system.
Featured a large 6-meter unfurlable antenna for S-band communication.
India's first multi-wavelength space observatory.
Carried Ku-band transponders and the GAGAN payload.
Fifth satellite of the NAVIC navigation system.
Sixth satellite of the NAVIC navigation system.
Seventh and final satellite to complete the initial NAVIC constellation.
Hypersonic flight experiment of the Reusable Launch Vehicle Technology Demonstrator.
Launched along with 19 co-passenger satellites.
An advanced meteorological satellite, a follow-on to INSAT-3D.
Continuity mission for Oceansat-2 scatterometer to provide wind vector data.
Carried C-band and Ku-band transponders.
Provided data continuity for the Resourcesat series.
Primary satellite in a record-setting launch of 104 satellites.
A communications satellite gifted by India for use by SAARC nations.
First developmental flight of the GSLV MkIII launch vehicle.
High-resolution earth observation satellite.
Carried communication payloads and satellite-aided search and rescue equipment.
The payload fairing failed to separate, trapping the satellite inside.
Communication was lost with the satellite two days after launch.
Replacement satellite for the failed IRNSS-1A.
High-throughput satellite for remote area connectivity.
Hyperspectral Imaging Satellite for advanced Earth observation.
Heaviest satellite built by ISRO, providing high-speed internet connectivity.
A military communications satellite for the Indian Air Force.
An imaging satellite that later served as the target for an anti-satellite (ASAT) missile test.
A telecommunications satellite to provide continuity to INSAT-4CR services.
An electronic intelligence satellite for the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO).
A radar imaging satellite for all-weather surveillance.
Orbiter remains operational, but the lander (Vikram) and rover (Pragyan) failed during the landing attempt.
Advanced high-resolution earth observation satellite.
Radar imaging satellite for all-weather surveillance.
A telecommunications satellite designed to replace the aging INSAT-4A.
An all-weather Radar Imaging Satellite, also known as RISAT-2BR2.
A communications satellite intended to replace GSAT-12.
Primary payload from Brazil. First dedicated commercial mission for NSIL.
Launch failed due to a technical anomaly in the cryogenic upper stage.
Radar Imaging Satellite to provide high-quality images under all weather conditions.
Co-passenger with EOS-04, a precursor to the India-Bhutan joint satellite.
Co-passenger with EOS-04, a student satellite.
Primary commercial payload from Singapore for NSIL.
Maiden developmental flight of the SSLV failed to place the satellite into a usable orbit.
Mission 'Prarambh'. First launch of a privately developed rocket in India by Skyroot Aerospace.
Provides continuity services for the Oceansat series with enhanced payload capabilities.
Co-passenger with EOS-06; A joint satellite with Bhutan.
Co-passenger with EOS-06; A hyperspectral nanosatellite from startup Pixxel.
Co-passengers with EOS-06; Nanosatellites for amateur radio from Dhruva Space.
Second developmental flight and first successful flight of the SSLV.
First of the second-generation NavIC satellites with an indigenous atomic clock.
Achieved a historic successful soft landing on the lunar south pole.
India's first dedicated solar observatory; successfully entered halo orbit in Jan 2024.
A high-throughput satellite launched by SpaceX for NSIL, not on an ISRO vehicle.
An ESA mission launched by ISRO to demonstrate precision formation flying.
Twin satellite mission to demonstrate autonomous rendezvous and docking technology.
Second satellite in the second-generation NavIC constellation.
An advanced Earth observation microsatellite.
A joint NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar mission for Earth science.
Did not achieve the desired altitude, resulting in an orbital life of only 9 days.
Launch failed as the indigenous cryogenic upper stage did not ignite.
A dedicated satellite for DTH services; launched by Arianespace for NSIL.
